description:
This year’s budget, more than any other in modern memory, will be about allocating pain as Kasich and lawmakers try to make up a shortfall of as much as $8 billion.

How painful will the decisions be? We’re here to give you a firsthand look. Using a budget calculator idea we borrowed from an interactive New York Times feature last November on the federal budget, you can elevate your knowledge - and have a little fun playing with the state budget.

With help from our partners at the nonprofit Center for Community Solutions, we have come up with 41 choices to save or bring in money to close the budget gap. The choices are listed in an interactive budget widget on Cleveland.com, so you can build your own version of the state budget and see how much progress you make in balancing it. The goal: turn the red dots to black.

Can you balance the state budget? Give it a try now.

Next to each of the 41 items in the interactive tool, we give you a little capsule - why it might be a good idea to pick this option and why it might be a bad one. Throw in a bad hairdo and some yard signs and you’re practically a state lawmaker on the finance committee.

Try your hand at balancing the state budget.

The idea here is simple - spark a little conversation about the state budget and maybe get people thinking about the tradeoffs and decisions that political decision-makers will grapple with until the two-year budget is put to rest in late June. We’re talking about big money. The last two-year general fund budget was $50.5 billion.

“Most people don’t understand the ins and outs of the state budget. It’s an enormously complex undertaking with hundreds and hundreds of line items and thousands of pages of directions for the General Assembly,” said John Begala, executive director of the Center for Community Solutions. “There’s so much detail it’s hard for people to track how these things are meaningful to them.”

This isn’t every solution under the sun - costing out the impact of Senate Bill 5, which would overhaul the state’s collective-bargaining law, for example, seemed too difficult given that much of the savings depends on locally negotiated contracts that differ from community to community. And we steered clear of an option to privatize more state prisons since the details of how you do it can drastically alter the savings.

So before the inevitable descent into bickering, dickering and back-room wheeling and dealing begins, you better get to work. Here at the Civic Commons, you have the opportunity to engage in a different kind of online conversation about all of these options, even the ones that aren’t in the budget widget. So join the conversation, tell your friends and neighbors where you think the Governor and the General Assembly ought to cut, and where they ought to find more money, and what, if anything, ought to be privatized. And listen, too, to the ideas your friends and neighbors have. Maybe, if we’re lucky, we’ll convince a lawmaker or two to listen in, as well, and take your ideas back to Columbus.

(excerpted from The Plain Dealer, by Aaron Marshall)
